item.title: Waves
item.description: Wave model Standing Waves Light Physics.

item.title: Work, Energy, Power
item.description: Work: W = Fs\cos(\theta) Energy is the ability to do work. Unit in J, Joules. Kinetic: E_{k} = \frac{1}{2}mv^{2} Potential: E_{p} = mgh Spring: E_{E} = \frac{1}{2}kx^{2} Note: \theta is for acting on a body at an angle.

item.title: Standing Waves
item.description: On strings, this is actually a LONGITUDINAL WAVE! Which is what allows it to be at so many frequencies. The one you visualize is transverse waves! In tubes, open ends are anti nodes since the air molecules can move parallel to the direction of the wave.

item.title: Thermal Physics
item.description: Heat in Relation to Physics Black Body Radiation.

item.title: Proof of One Dimensional Collision
item.description: Start with momentum m_{1}v_{1} + m_{2}v_{2} = m_{1}v_{1}^{'} + m_{2}v_{2}^{'} Do the same for kinetic energy \frac{1}{2}m_{1}v_{1}^2 + \frac{1}{2}m_{2}v_{2}^2 ...

item.title: Light Physics
item.description: Light is a transverse wave that is perpendicular to the direction of travel. Light will reflect and refract at a change in medium as other waves due to a change in velocity.

item.title: Mechanics Physics
item.description: Kinematics Dynamics Momentum Physics Work, Energy, Power.

item.title: Momentum Physics
item.description: Momentum, p = mv . Newtonâ€™s second law can be written as: \sum F = \frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t} Momentum is conserved in all isolated, closed systems. Elastic collisions are when kinetic energy is conserved.
